name: BigQuery
description:
The object returned from gcloud.bigquery gives you complete access to and control of your BigQuery datasets. You can work with existing ones, by using the dataset method, or create new ones with createDataset.

To learn more about BigQuery, see What is BigQuery?

methods.name: BigQuery
methods.description: The examples below will demonstrate the different usage patterns your app may need to support to retrieve a BigQuery object.

examples.caption: In the following examples from this page and the other modules (Dataset, Table, etc.), we are going to be using a dataset from data.gov of higher education institutions. We will create a table with the correct schema, import the public CSV file into that table, and query it for data.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: dataset
methods.description: Create a reference to an existing dataset.

methods.name: getDatasets
methods.description: List all or some of the datasets in your project.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
Get the datasets from your project as a readable object stream.
If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: query.pageToken
params.description: • Token returned from a previous call, to request the next page of results.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.datasets
params.description: • The list of datasets in your project.

params.name: callback.nextQuery
params.description: • If present, query with this object to check for more results.

methods.name: getJobs
methods.description: Get all of the jobs from your project.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
Get the jobs from your project as a readable object stream.
If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: options.allUsers
params.description: • Display jobs owned by all users in the project.

params.name: options.pageToken
params.description: • Token returned from a previous call, to request the next page of results.

params.name: options.projection
params.description: • Restrict information returned to a set of selected fields. Acceptable values are "full", for all job data, and "minimal", to not include the job configuration.

params.name: options.stateFilter
params.description: • Filter for job state. Acceptable values are "done", "pending", and "running".

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.jobs
params.description: • The list of jobs in your project.

params.name: callback.nextQuery
params.description: • If present, query with this object to check for more results.

methods.name: job
methods.description: Create a reference to an existing Job.

methods.name: query
methods.description:
Run a query scoped to your project.

If you provide a callback, this method returns the results from your query to it. When querying large sets of data, it is possible your results won't be returned all at once. In those cases, you will receive a third argument to your callback that can be passed back to this method to return more results.

See the examples below for such a workflow.

This method also runs as a readable stream if you do not provide a callback. In cases where more results exist, this will automatically run the subsequent queries for you, pushing each row to the stream.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
You can also use the query method as a readable object stream by omitting the callback.

params.name: options
params.description: • A string SQL query or configuration object.

params.name: options.query
params.description: • A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute.

params.name: options.timeoutMs
params.description: • How long to wait for the query to complete, in milliseconds, before returning. Default is to return immediately. If the timeout passes before the job completes, the request will fail with a TIMEOUT error.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.rows
params.description: • The list of results from your query.

params.name: callback.nextQuery
params.description: • If present, query with this object to check for more results.

methods.name: startQuery
methods.description: Run a query as a job. No results are immediately returned. Instead, your callback will be executed with a bigquery/job object that you must ping for the results. See the Job documentation for explanations of how to check on the status of the job.

examples.caption: You may pass only a query string, having a new table created to store the results of the query.
You can also control the destination table by providing a bigquery/table object.
After you have run startQuery, your query will execute in a job. Your callback is executed with a bigquery/job object so that you may check for the results.

params.name: options
params.description: • The configuration object. This must be in the format of the configuration.query property of a Jobs resource. If a string is provided, this is used as the query string, and all other options are defaulted.

params.name: options.destination
params.description: • The table to save the query's results to. If omitted, a new table will be created.

params.name: options.query
params.description: • A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.job
params.description: • The newly created job for your query.

exceptions.description: If a Table is not provided as a destination.
